channel.title: Biorxiv on Paul Hook
channel.description: Recent content in Biorxiv on Paul Hook

item.title: Scraping bioRxiv
item.description: Scraping bioRxiv This post is the first of a series focusing on tracking preprints on bioRxiv. The motivation behind this and a more detailed explanantion can be found here scraping in R When I first began to approach preprint tracking, the mysterious world of “HTML scraping” seemed like something that would help. Scraping seemed like a good idea because: A) It doesn’t seem like there are simple/easy ways to access a bioRxiv database that holds such information and B) Whether or not the paper is published is displayed clearly on each preprint’s page (see below).

item.title: Keeping track of preprints
item.description: Premise For my first set of blog posts, I have decided to start a series about preprints. Awhile ago, an interesting question was brought up by Shannon Ellis in her wonderful blog post “Let there be preprint citations!” (emphasis is mine): Problem #2: Preprints often become peer-reviewed research. How will we keep track? Solution #2a (if this occurs during while the manuscript is being drafted): It is up to the author(s) to ensure that their manuscript is as up to date as possible upon submission for publication.
